S.FORM: == balaysan == 高粱 balaysan ku sapisanga' tu epah. siwkay nu balaysan u balaysan sa, u nipaluma nu niyazu'. cacay a mihca tabakiay a lutuk. hali caledes, caay katalaw tu caledes,caay katalaw tu balad. kya paenu' sa kya kulit u sumanahay atu sangelacay. mukan ku tademaw, mukan tu ku aadupan. taneng misanga' tu epah. u kapahay a nipaluma nu niyazu'. u balaysan a papah siwalak, sisa amana mukan kya papah, amana pakan tu aadupan. izaw ku kungku nu Sakizaya, izaw ku sibalaysan a subal, u tatayna amin, inayi' ku tatama. tinaku a kamu mibalaysan 採高粱 mibalaysan ku malukay tu pituway a bulad nu miheca. mibalaysanay 採高梁的 tanutuwa' sa mudaliw ku mibalaysanay a tademaw. sibalaysan 有高粱 sibalaysan ku ni palumaan ni Tubah a kubkub. sibalaysanay 有高粱的 nayi' tu ku sibalaysanay nu malukay ayza. u sulit nu Hulam atu Amilika Sorghum bicolor, commonly called sorghum (/'sɔːrɡəm/) and also known as great millet, durra, jowari, or milo, is a grass species cultivated for its grain, which is used for food, both for animals and humans, and for ethanol production. Sorghum originated in northern Africa, and is now cultivated widely in tropical and subtropical regions. Sorghum is the world's fifth most important cereal crop after rice, wheat, maize and barley. S. bicolor is typically an annual, but some cultivars are perennial. It grows in clumps that may reach over 4 m high. The grain is small, ranging from 2 to 4 mm in diameter. Sweet sorghums are sorghum cultivars that are primarily grown for foliage, syrup production, and ethanol; they are taller than those grown for grain.

== balaysan == 高粱 balaysan ko sapisanga' to epah. siwkay no balaysan o balaysan sa, o nipaloma no niyazo'. cacay a mihca tabakiay a lotok. hali caledes, caay katalaw to caledes,caay katalaw to balad. kya paeno' sa kya kolit o somanahay ato sangelacay. mokan ko tademaw, mokan to ko aadopan. taneng misanga' to epah. o kapahay a nipaloma no niyazo'. o balaysan a papah siwalak, sisa amana mokan kya papah, amana pakan to aadopan. izaw ko kongko no Sakizaya, izaw ko sibalaysan a sobal, o tatayna amin, inayi' ko tatama. tinako a kamo mibalaysan 採高粱 mibalaysan ko malokay to pitoway a bolad no miheca. mibalaysanay 採高梁的 tanotowa' sa modaliw ko mibalaysanay a tademaw. sibalaysan 有高粱 sibalaysan ko ni palomaan ni Tobah a kobkob. sibalaysanay 有高粱的 nayi' to ko sibalaysanay no malokay ayza. o solit no Holam ato Amilika Sorghom bicolor, commonly called sorghom (/'sɔːrɡəm/) and also known as great millet, dorra, jowari, or milo, is a grass species coltivated for its grain, which is osed for food, both for animals and homans, and for ethanol prodoction. Sorghom originated in northern Africa, and is now coltivated widely in tropical and sobtropical regions. Sorghom is the world's fifth most important cereal crop after rice, wheat, maize and barley. S. bicolor is typically an annoal, bot some coltivars are perennial. It grows in clomps that may reach over 4 m high. The grain is small, ranging from 2 to 4 mm in diameter. Sweet sorghoms are sorghom coltivars that are primarily grown for foliage, syrop prodoction, and ethanol; they are taller than those grown for grain.
